name: Second Harvest Food Bank
mission: Summer Meals Second Harvest works with school districts and community partners to maximize the use of federally funded school meals.
theoryOfChange: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley has a published theory of change for its 'One Community Initiative'. This framework was developed in partnership with Project Evident to understand the program's impact on client experiences, food insecurity, and hunger outcomes. The strategy for this initiative includes a theory of change, prioritized outcome measures, a design for internal evaluation, and a learning agenda to guide future evaluation.

judge_issues.message: BBB name 'Second Harvest Food Bank of North Central Ohio' may not match 'Second Harvest Food Bank' (similarity: 57%)

score_details.score_summary: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley earns 63/100 due to good impact and good alignment.

zakat.claim_evidence: No explicit mention of "zakat" or "zakat-compliant donations" was found on the official donation pages or website of Second Harvest of Silicon Valley. The organization's donation information focuses on general monetary, food, and item donations, as well as various giving methods like donor-advised funds, IRA gifts, and cryptocurrency, without any specific reference to zakat.

all_citations.claim: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley holds a 100.0/100 rating for accountability and financial health.
The organization reported total revenue of $286,205,684 and a program expense ratio of 94.8%.
The organization provides food assistance to an average monthly client base through various grocery programs.
Second Harvest provides significant grants and assistance to domestic organizations and individuals to facilitate food access.
The organization accepts general donations and offers various giving methods for charitable supporters.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a 63/100 reflecting a perfect financial health score from third-party evaluators balanced against a medium alignment for donors seeking specific Islamic-oriented causes.
areas_for_improvement: High cost per beneficiary relative to some international relief models
Limited specific alignment with Islamic philanthropic frameworks beyond general sadaqah

dimension_explanations.alignment: Addressing hunger in Silicon Valley is categorized as a cause of extreme urgency given the high local cost of living [1]. While the organization is a reliable recipient for general sadaqah or charitable giving, it does not have specific religious programming, resulting in a medium donor fit for those seeking faith-specific alignment [5].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates direct provision of services with a perfect Charity Navigator score of 100.0/100, indicating top-tier accountability and financial health [1]. While the cost per beneficiary is calculated at approximately $528.78, the high program expense ratio of 94.8% ensures that the vast majority of funds directly support food distribution and community partners [2][4].

baseline_narrative.headline: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley serves as a critical food bank lifeline, distributing nutritious groceries and maximizing federal meal programs to combat extreme poverty in Northern California.
strengths: Exceptional financial efficiency with a program expense ratio of 94.8%
Highly efficient fundraising operations costing only $0.03 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 9.5 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley operates as a major hunger-relief organization, distributing food through grocery programs and community partnerships to address food insecurity [1][3]. The organization reported a total revenue of $286,205,684 while maintaining a high program expense ratio of 94.8% [2].

case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="15">declining revenue trends</cite> and a high cost-of-service delivery model inherent to its geographic focus.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data from 2023; Ratings from late 2024
confidence.notes: Extremely high data availability and third-party verification.

credibility.explanation: Donors can have high confidence due to <cite id="16">20/20 standards met with the BBB Wise Giving Alliance</cite> and a <cite id="11">Candid Platinum Seal</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To further enhance credibility, the organization could publish more frequent <cite id="17">external evaluation documents</cite> beyond the two currently available.

impact.improvement: The charity could improve its impact score by <cite id="18">reducing the cost per beneficiary</cite> through further optimization of its local distribution logistics.

rich_narrative.headline: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley serves as a critical food bank lifeline, distributing nutritious groceries and maximizing federal meal programs to combat extreme poverty in Northern California.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support high-efficiency, large-scale hunger relief in Northern California through a highly transparent, institutional-grade nonprofit.
donor_motivations: Want to address local poverty in the Silicon Valley region
Value organizations with perfect 100/100 transparency ratings
Prefer charities with extremely low fundraising overhead ($0.03 per $1)
Seek to support a regional backbone that empowers other local charities
giving_considerations: The high cost of living in the service area results in a higher cost per beneficiary
The organization is currently in a revenue contraction phase
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking to maximize the number of lives saved per dollar globally or those specifically looking to fulfill Zakat obligations.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The charity tracks <cite id="22">4 distinct outcome metrics</cite> and has <cite id="17">2 external evaluation documents</cite>.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Second Harvest uses a multi-pronged approach: direct food distribution, maximizing federal meal program participation, and advocacy to transition from crisis response to sustainable community health.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that food distribution actually reduces hunger levels and improves nutritional outcomes for the 500,000 clients served.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the organization has strong reserves, the <cite id="15">declining revenue trend</cite> suggests a need for renewed donor engagement to maintain service levels.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: Santa Clara and San Mateo Counties

peer_comparison.differentiator: Maintains a <cite id="3">94.6% program ratio</cite>, which is highly competitive, though slightly below the <cite id="21">peer median of 98.3%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Focuses on housing rather than food security

strengths.detail: The organization maintains a <cite id="3">94.8% program expense ratio</cite> and spends only <cite id="8">$0.03 to raise every $1</cite>.
Second Harvest holds a <cite id="9">perfect 100.0/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting top-tier transparency and governance.
The charity maintains <cite id="10">9.5 months of working capital</cite>, providing significant stability against economic fluctuations.

strengths_deep_dive: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley demonstrates institutional-grade management, evidenced by its <cite id="11">Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>. Their financial health is bolstered by a highly independent board, with <cite id="12">94% independent members</cite> overseeing operations. This governance structure supports a massive logistical undertaking that distributed <cite id="13">$126 million in grants and assistance to domestic organizations</cite> in a single year, effectively acting as a regional hub for dozens of smaller food pantries and community groups.
rich_narrative.summary: Second Harvest of Silicon Valley is a premier hunger-relief organization that has served Northern California since its <cite id="1">founding in 1974</cite>. Operating in one of the most expensive regions in the United States, the organization serves as a critical backbone for food security, reporting <cite id="2">$286,205,684 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year. The charity distinguishes itself through exceptional operational efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 94.8%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of resources are converted directly into nutritional support. Their model is multifaceted, combining <cite id="4">direct grocery programs</cite> with advocacy and <cite id="5">CalFresh outreach</cite> to address the root causes of food insecurity. On average, the organization has supported <cite id="6">500,000 monthly clients</cite>, providing a vital safety net for families, seniors, and students. By leveraging <cite id="7">79 domestic grant recipients</cite> and a vast network of community partners, Second Harvest maximizes the reach of federally funded school meals and local food distributions.
